sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw, êh-nîsicik owîkimâkanah, itah êh-wîkicik.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ê-nîsicik owîkimâkana ita ê-wîkicik
sentences.english: Once upon a time there was a man who lived alone somewhere with only his wife.
The man used to hunt.

sentences.original: kâ-nipahât mostoswah, êh-takohtêt owîkiwâhk, êh-wîhtamawât owîkimâkanah, wawêyîw awâ iskwêw, êh-wîh-nâtahk wiyâsah.
sentences.text: kâ-nipahât mostoswa ê-takohtêt wîkiwâhk ê-wîhtamawât owîkimâkana wawêyîw awa iskwêw ê-wî-nâtahk wiyâsa
sentences.english: When he had killed buffalo, as he arrived at their tipi and told his wife, the woman would make ready to fetch the meat.
She would pull out a dried sinew and scorch it in the fire.
The sinew would shrivel up small.

sentences.original: ômis îsi ta-kisiwâkiwiw, kâ-wîh-nâtamân wiyâsah! itwêw awah iskwêw.
sentences.english: “Even thus let it be near whence I am to fetch the meats!” she would say.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-wayawît, ê-sipwêhtêt, êh-nâtahk wiyâsah, tâpwêw kisiwâk otihtam, êh-otinahk, êh-kîwêhtatât.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-wayawît ê-sipwêhtêt ê-nâtahk wiyâsa tâpwê kisiwâk otihtam ê-otinahk ê-kîwêhtatât
sentences.english: Thereupon, when she left the tipi and went forth to fetch the meat, she would in fact come to it close by, and take it and bring it home.

sentences.original: wâh, itêyihtam awa nâpêw, tâpwê kâh-kiyipah pêtâw wiyâsah, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Dear me,” thought the man, “truly she is always quick about bringing the meat,” thought he.

sentences.original: êkosi kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam wîwah êh-misikitiyit, êh-pwâwiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam wîwa ê-misikitiyit ê-pwâwiyit
sentences.english: Then presently he know that his wife was big with child.
He stayed right there;

sentences.original: namoya wîh-mâcîw, kiyâm ta-miyopayiw, êh-itêyimât ôwîkimâkanah; êkâ ka-misi-wanâcihât ôh âwâsisah watâhk k-âsôwâsôwit, itêyihtam awa nâpêw.
sentences.text: namôya wî-mâcîw ê-itêyimât owîkimâkana itêyihtam awa nâpêw
sentences.english: he did not care to hunt, thinking of his wife, “Pray that it may go well with her, that she may not lose the child that is in her womb,” thought the man.

sentences.original: pôtih kîtahtawê âhkosiyiwa ôwîkimâkanah, ê-wîh-wâpamâcik ôh âwâsisah.
sentences.text: pôti kîtahtawê âhkosiyiwa owîkimâkana ê-wî-wâpamâcik ôhi awâsisa
sentences.english: Presently, there, his wife fell ill, for they were about to see their child.
And indeed, when darkness came, she was forced to her couch.
They saw their child.

sentences.original: mistahi miywêyihtam awa nâpêw êh-otawâsimisiyit wîwah êyôkonih.
sentences.text: mistahi miywêyihtam awa nâpêw ê-otawâsimisiyit wîwa êwakoni
sentences.english: The man was very glad that his wife had given birth to a child.
And this child was Wisahketchahk.
So they cared for him and brought him up.
In time this Wisahketchahk grew big.
Again they had a child.
This one, too, was born.
This one, too, was a boy.
Wisahketchahk had a little brother.
He was glad of it.
So they lived in that place.
In time those children grew big.
And that man did nothing but hunt.

sentences.original: êkwah aw îskwêw êh-nikohtêt mânah, nah-nama-mayaw takohtêw aw iskwêw.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw ê-nikohtêt mâna na-nama-mayaw takohtêw awa iskwêw
sentences.english: Now, when that woman gathered firewood, she had a way of not coming back on time.

sentences.original: namoya êkwah atoskêw êkoyikohk, itêyimêw ôwîkimâkanah awa nâpêw, osâm kâh-kinwêsk êh-nikohtêyit;
sentences.text: itêyimêw owîkimâkana awa nâpêw osâm kâh-kinwêsk ê-nikohtêyit
sentences.english: “Now, she does not work as long as this,” thought the man of his wife, when again and again she took too long about gathering wood;
“What is it she does?” he thought of her;
“I had better try and find out what sort of thing delays her;
she is all day gathering firewood,” thought he of his wife.

sentences.original: kîkisêpâ wawêyîw, ê-wîh-mâcît, ê-sipwêhtêt, êkwah itêh kâ-nikohtêyit owîkimâkanah, êkotê êh-itohtêt.
sentences.text: kîkisêpâ wawêyîw ê-wî-mâcît ê-sipwêhtêt êkwa itê kâ-nikohtêyit owîkimâkana êkotê ê-itohtêt
sentences.english: The next morning he made ready to go hunting and set out and went to where his wife got firewood.
There he hid from his wife.
Presently she came walking that way, at her task of getting firewood.

sentences.original: êh-pê-takohtêyit êkotah sakâhk, kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit mistikwah êh-kîskipayiyit.
sentences.text: ê-pê-takohtêyit êkota sakâhk kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit mistikwa ê-kîskipayiyit
sentences.english: When she arrived there in the grove, he noticed a large cleft tree.
By it his wife took her stand, and took off her clothes until she stood naked.

sentences.original: otinam mistik aw îskwêw, ôhi mistikwah kâ-misikitiyit êh-pa-pakamahwât aw îskwêw.
sentences.text: otinam mistik awa iskwêw ôhi mistikwa kâ-misikitiyit ê-pa-pakamahwât awa iskwêw
sentences.english: She took up a stick and began to beat that large tree.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêw : ninâpêmitik! itwêw, kâ-wâpamât awa nâpêw mihcêt êh-wayawiyit mistikohk ohci kinêpikwah.
sentences.text: ômisi itwêw itwêw kâ-wâpamât awa nâpêw mihcêt ê-wayawiyit mistikohk ohci kinêpikwa
sentences.english: This was what she said: “O my husbands!” she said, and then the man saw a great many serpents come forth from the tree.

sentences.original: êkosi nahapiw aw îskwêw, êh-pimisihk, misiwê êkotah êh-papâmâhtawêyit ôhi kinêpikwah aw îskwêw wiyawihk.
sentences.text: êkosi nahapiw awa iskwêw ê-pimisihk misiwê êkota ê-papâmâhtawêyit ôhi kinêpikwa awa iskwêw wiyawihk
sentences.english: At that the woman lay down flat and those serpents climbed this way and that all over her body.

sentences.original: piyisk namoya wâpamêw owîkimâkanah, osâm misiwê êh-ayâyit kinêpikwah.
sentences.text: piyisk namôya wâpamêw owîkimâkana osâm misiwê ê-ayâyit kinêpikwa
sentences.english: Soon he could no longer see his wife, for the serpents were all over her.

sentences.original: êkos îsi sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw, wâhyaw êh-nitawih-nipahât mostoswah.
sentences.text: êkosi isi sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw wâhyaw ê-nitawi-nipahât mostoswa
sentences.english: Thereupon that man went away; he went far away and killed a buffalo.
It was dark before he got home.
At last he arrived; in deep darkness he came home from his tramp.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-wâpahk, ninêstosin, itwêw awa nâpêw;
sentences.english: Then, the next morning, “I am tired,” said the man;
“I am not going to hunt,” he told his wife.
The woman made ready to fetch the meat.
She took a sinew and scorched it.

sentences.original: ômisi t-êsi-kisiwâkiwiw kâ-wîh-nâtamân wiyâsah! itwêw aw îskwêw, êh-ati-wayawît.
sentences.english: “Even thus let it be near whence I am to fetch the meats!” she said, going out of the tent.

sentences.original: awa nâpêw otinam ôm âstisis kâ-kîh-matostêhamiyit owîkimâkanah, ê-sîpêkipitahk, ta-wîh-pîhcâyiw kâ-nâtahk wiyâsah! êh-itât owîkimâkanah, cikêmâ êh-kisiwâsit.
sentences.text: awa nâpêw otinam ôma astisis kâ-kî-macostêhamiyit owîkimâkana ê-sîpêkipitahk ê-itât owîkimâkana cikêmâ ê-kisiwâsit
sentences.english: The man took the little bit of sinew which his wife had scorched, and stretched it long, saying, of his wife, “Let it be far whence she fetches the meats!”

sentences.original: hâw, hâw, ntawâsimisitik, namoya ês ôyâh kwayask êh-tôtahk kikâwiyiwâw, kâ-kinwêsk kâ-nikohtêt.
sentences.english: “Come, my children, it seems that your mother who has left has been acting in no becoming way, when always so long she was at gathering firewood.
I have seen what she did; it is hateful to me.
Flee,” he told them;
“I am going to kill your mother,” he told them.
He pulled up a tent-pole.

sentences.original: hâw, nitawâsimisitik, ôtah kwayasitêk; tapasîk! itwêw.
sentences.english: “Come, my children, go into this hole; flee!” he said.
Then those boys went in there.

sentences.original: kâw êkotah astâw apasoy, êh-tapasiyit otawâsimisah.
sentences.text: kâwi êkota astâw apasoy ê-tapasîyit otawâsimisa
sentences.english: He put back the tent-pole, and his children fled.

sentences.original: êkwah awa nâpêw otinêw askihkwah êkwah cîkahikan, ê-sipwêhtêt, êh-itohtêt ôhi mistikwah kâ-kîh-pa-pakamahwâyit owîkimâkanah.
sentences.text: êkwa awa nâpêw otinêw askihkwa êkwa cîkahikan ê-sipwêhtêt ê-itohtêt ôhi mistikwa kâ-kî-pa-pakamahwâyit owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Then that man took a kettle and an axe and went, off, going to that tree which his wife had struck.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêw, êh-otinahk mistik, êh-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwah : ninâpêmitik, nitakohtân! itêw.
sentences.text: ômisi itwêw ê-otinahk mistik ê-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwa itêw
sentences.english: Taking up a stick of wood and repeatedly striking the tree, he said, “O my husbands, I have come!”

sentences.original: pôtih êh-pê-wayawiyit kinêpikwah, cîkahwêw; nipahêw, êkotah askihkohk mihkoh êh-ati-sîkinahk; wiy ôhi wêpinêw.
sentences.text: pôti ê-pê-wayawiyit kinêpikwa cîkahwêw nipahêw êkota askihkohk mihko ê-ati-sîkinahk wiya ôhi wêpinêw
sentences.english: Then, look you, when the serpents came forth, he hacked them with the axe and killed them, but always poured the blood into the kettle; what was left of them he threw away.

sentences.original: piyê-wayawiyici, ati-nipahêw, askihkohk tahk êh-astât mihkoh.
sentences.text: piyê-wayawiyici ati-nipahêw askihkohk tahki ê-astât mihko
sentences.english: He kept killing them as they came forth, and always put the blood in the kettle.
At last he had killed all of those serpents.
Thereupon he went home; he took the blood home with him.
Then he heated it.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-ay-apit, piyisk kêkâc tipiskâw; êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit owîkimâkanah, êh-pêtâyit wiyâs.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-ay-apit piyisk kêkâc tipiskâw êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit owîkimâkana ê-pêtâyit wiyâs
sentences.english: As he sat there, at last it began to grow dark; only then did his wife arrive, bringing the meat.

sentences.original: omis îtwêw aw îskwêw : tâpwêh wâhyaw kikîh-nipahâw mostos! itwêw aw iskwêw;
sentences.text: ômisi itwêw awa iskwêw itwêw awa iskwêw
sentences.english: Thus spoke that woman: “Truly far off did you kill the buffalo!” she said;

sentences.original: kêsiskaw nika-nikohtân; sâm kiyipah ta-tipiskâw, itwêw.
sentences.english: “First I shall get firewood; soon it will be dark,” she said.
“Wait!” said the man;
“First eat this,” he told his wife;
“Eat this blood which I have prepared,” he told her.

sentences.original: namoya; osâm nipapâsêyihtên ê-wîh-nikohtêyân, itwêw aw îskwêw.
sentences.english: “No; I must hurry and get my firewood,” said the woman.

sentences.original: kêsiskaw mîcisoh; kayâs kâ-kîh-mîcisoyan, itêw owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: “First eat; it is a long time since you have eaten,” he said to his wife.
“Very well,” said the woman.
She went into the tipi and took the blood and drank it.

sentences.original: î! tâpwê ê-wîhkasiniyik awa! itwêw aw îskwêw.
sentences.english: “Ooh! Truly this creature's blood tastes good!” she said.
“Do you recognize the taste of it?” the man asked her.

sentences.original: êhag; mihkoh mâk ôma, itwêw awa iskwêw.
sentences.english: “Yes, why, this is blood,” said she.
“Your husband's blood!” he said to his wife.
sentences.footnote: LB on {kinâpêm-mihkoh}:  “Your husbands blood” would be {kinâpêmak omihkowâw}; what we have here is a nonce-formation on the model of the normal type {kinêpiko-mihkoh}: “snake-blood”, in which the first member is a species of animal.

sentences.original: nâ, mâkw âwa nika-kakwâhyakihikoh! itwêw aw îskwêw, êh-ati-wayawît, êh-itohtêt ôhi mistikwah.
sentences.text: itwêw awa iskwêw ê-ati-wayawît ê-itohtêt ôhi mistikwa
sentences.english: “Heavens, but he has frightened me!” cried the woman, as she left the tent and went to that tree.
sentences.footnote: LB on {mâkw âwa}:  For {mâk âwa, mâkah awa}; so often, on the model of {êwakw âwa, êwakoh awah} and similar combinations, where the first word ends in {-o}.

sentences.original: mistik êh-otinahk, êh-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwah, ninâpêmitik, nitakosinin! itwêw aw iskwêw, pêyak êh-apisîsisiyit kâ-pê-wayawiyit.
sentences.text: mistik ê-otinahk ê-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwa itwêw awa iskwêw pêyak ê-apisîsisiyit kâ-pê-wayawiyit
sentences.english: Taking up a stick and beating at the tree, “O my husbands, I have come!” called the woman, and one tiny little one came out.
She was angry; she went home.

sentences.original: êkwah awa nâpêw cîkahikan otinam, kisiwâk ê-pê-ayâyit owîkimâkana.
sentences.text: êkwa awa nâpêw cîkahikan otinam kisiwâk ê-pê-ayâyit owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Then that man took an axe, as his wife came near.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêw aw iskwêw : kikisiwâhin kâ-mêscihacik ninâpêmak! itwêw.
sentences.english: Thus spoke the woman: “You have angered me by killing all my husbands!” she cried.
As she was about to enter the lodge, he struck his wife with the axe; he chopped off his wife's head.
Then he fled; way up aloft he went.

sentences.original: hâw, ayîsiyiniw cêskwah ôtêh nîkân tit-ôhpikiw;
sentences.english: “Now, off in the future man will grow into being;
'The Great Star,' they will say.
That will be I,” said the man.

sentences.original: êkwah aw iskwêw ostikwân tihtipipayiyiw, êh-ntonawât onâpêma.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw ostikwân tihtipipayiyiw ê-nitonawât onâpêma
sentences.english: Then that woman's head went rolling, as she sought her husband.
At last she perceived whither her husband had gone.
“There, my husband, you were fond of them; you shall have buttocks!
Go follow our husband, 0 my buttocks!”
sentences.footnote: The father turns into the constellation called {okînânis}.  As to the buttocks, the Menomini have a constellation {awêhseh osîkan}: “Bear's Rump”.

sentences.original: êkwah awa oma ostikwân oma tihtipipayiw, êh-ntonawât otawâsimisah.
sentences.text: êkwa awa ôma ostikwân ôma tihtipipayiw ê-nitonawât otawâsimisa
sentences.english: Then that head went rolling, as she sought her children.
“If I find them, I shall kill off your children,” she called to her husband.
That Rolling Head searched everywhere.

sentences.original: piyisk miskam itah kâ-kwayasitêyit otawâsimisah, êkwah êh-pimitisahwât.
sentences.text: piyisk miskam ita kâ-kwayasitêyit otawâsimisa êkwa ê-pimitisahwât
sentences.english: At last she found the place where her children had gone into the ground, and she started in pursuit of them.
Far off those children had emerged and gone on in their flight.

sentences.original: êwako, ôki nâpêsisak, wîsahkêcâhk êwako âskaw êh-nayômât osîmisah.
sentences.text: êwako ôki nâpêsisak wîsahkêcâhk êwako âskaw ê-nayômât osîmisa
sentences.english: As to those boys, Wisahketchahk from time to time would carry his little brother on his back.

sentences.original: piyisk kisiwâk ayâyiwa okâwiyiwâwa, ôhih tihtipistikwânah.
sentences.text: piyisk kisiwâk ayâyiwa okâwiyiwâwa ôhi tihtipistikwâna
sentences.english: At last quite near was their mother, that Rolling Head.
“My children, wait for me! I want to suckle your little brother,” she called to them.
Soon that child cried.
“Big Brother, let us wait for our mother!” he said.
“No! Our mother there wants to kill us!” he told him.

sentences.original: ntowâsimisitik, pêhik! tahk êh-itât, piyisk kisiwâk êh-êh-ayâyit, hâw, itwêw wîsahkêcâhk, sîpiy otah ta-wîh-ayâw!
sentences.text: tahki ê-itât piyisk kisiwâk ê-ay-ayâyit itwêw wîsahkêcâhk
sentences.english: “My children, wait for me!” it kept saying to them, and at last had come very near, when, “Here,” said Wisahketchahk, “Let there be a river here!”
When he spoke thus, there was a stream blocking his path, and there he saw a crane.
“Take us across the water, Crane;
our mother wants to kill us,” he said to it.
“Very well,” it told them; “Come, my grandchildren!”
By this time their mother had come very close.
The crane took them on its back and was about to cross the water.
Their mother arrived.
Crane, bring me my children;
sentences.footnote: LB on {câhcak}:  For {câhcakiw}: “crane”; she makes a personal name of it by dropping the final {-iw}, cf. e.g., {cîhcîkwâyôw}: “Gnawed-Tail” (as a man's name), for {cîhcîkwâyôwêw}: “he is gnawed at the tail.”

sentences.english: I am sad with longing to suckle my child.”
“Do not believe her, Grandfather!” Wisahketchahk told it.
Wisahketchahk was taken across.
Then the crane swam back yonder.
Come here!” cried that Rolling Head;
“Take me across the water;
I am sad with longing to suckle my child.
If you like, I will even lie with you,” she told it.

sentences.original: âhag, itwêw awa câhcakêw; hâw, ka-nayômitin.
sentences.english: “Very well, said the crane; “Come, I will take you on my back.”
It took her on its back.
“Do not move; my spine is very sensitive,” meaning that it had a pain in its back.
Then it started off.

sentences.original: osâm pêyahtik êh-pimohtêt, kisiskâhtêh! itêw awa tihtipistikwân; ninohtê-nôhâwasôwâh awa! omisî êh-ispayihot, êh-nâh-nâmipayihot.
sentences.text: osâm pêyâhtik ê-pimohtêt itêw awa tihtipistikwân ômisi ê-ispayihot ê-nâh-namipayihot
sentences.english: When it went too slowly, “Go fast!” the Rolling Head cried at it; “I am in distress with the need of suckling this child!” and it threw itself about like this, bobbing up and down.
The crane winced and ducked;
into the water went that Rolling Head.

sentences.original: omis îtwêw awa cahcakiw; hâw, cêskwah nîkân ôtêh ayîsiyiniw kit-ôhpikiw;
sentences.english: Thus spoke the crane: “There, off in yon future time man will come into being;
'Sturgeon,' they will call you,” it said to that Rolling Head.
sentences.footnote: LB:  But the same informat tells me that Wisahketchak's mother is now the constellation called {cihcipistikwân}: “Rolling-Skull.”

sentences.original: êkwah tâpwê mistahi mâtôw awa wîsahkêcâhk osîmisah, êh-wâpamât okâwiyah êh-pakastawêhomiht.
sentences.text: êkwa tâpwê mistahi mâtôw awa wîsahkêcâhk osîmisa ê-wâpamât okâwiya ê-pakastawêhomiht
sentences.english: Then truly Wisahketchahk's little brother wept much, when he saw his mother thrown into the water.
sentences.footnote: LB on {osîmisah}:  This construction, joining a non-obviative pronominal particle ({awa}) to an obviative noun, and using non-obviative verbs with the combination is usual in Menomini, but decidedly awkward in Cree.

sentences.original: nisîmis, êkaya mâtoh; ê-kih-wînipahikoyahk kikâwiyinaw, itêw osîmisah.
sentences.english: “Little Brother, do not weep; it is because our mother wanted to kill us,” he told his little brother.
There they stayed by the river, and he amused his little brother by making him play.
Then at one time he saw an old man who came paddling a canoe.

sentences.original: ôhih osîmisah pâkahatôwânisah êh-mêtawâkêyit, ômisi itêyihtam awa kisêyiniw : ohpiwêpinâci ôtah ka-pê-pôsipayiyiwah! itêyihtam.
sentences.text: ôhi osîmisa pâkahatôwânisa ê-mêtawâkêyit ômisi itêyihtam awa kisêyiniw itêyihtam
sentences.english: As Wisahketchahk's little brother played there with his ball, the old man thought: “When he throws it aloft, let it fall here into my canoe!”

sentences.original: êy-ohpiwêpinât aw âwâsis pâkahâcôwânisah, êkotê pahkisiniyiwa.
sentences.text: ê-ohpiwêpinât awa awâsis pâkahacôwânisa êkotê pahkisiniyiwa
sentences.english: When the child threw his little ball up into the air, there it fell.
He took it and started to paddle away.
Then truly that little boy cried.

sentences.original: nimosôh, itêw aw wîsahkêcâhk, pê-kapâwêpin nisîmis opâkahâcowânisah!
sentences.english: “Grandfather,” Wisahketchahk called to him, “Throw my little brother's ball back here to the shore!
That is what would make him stop crying!” he told him.
“Yes, Grandchild, come fetch it!”

sentences.original: êkosi ê-wîh-nâtât, otapoyiwa êkotah êh-ati-mitimêyâhtawêt wîsahkêcâhk, kâ-pôsiwêpahokot ôhi ksêyiniwa.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-wî-nâtât otapoyiwa êkota ê-ati-mitimêyâhtawêt wîsahkêcâhk kâ-pôsiwêpahokot ôhi kisêyiniwa
sentences.english: When, accordingly, Wisahketchahk came to fetch it, and was climbing out by holding on to the paddle, the old man threw him down into the canoe.
Then he started off, so that they left Wisahketchahk's little brother behind.
The child wept bitterly.
“Grandfather, we are making my little brother unhappy! Do let us go get him!” he said to the old man.
The old man paid no heed.
Soon he was far off.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê awa awâsis kâ-mâtot îtwêw : nistêsê, tâpwê kikitimahin kâ-nakasiyan! itwêw;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê awa awâsis kâ-mâtot itwêw itwêw
sentences.english: Presently that child that was weeping cried out: “Big Brother, truly you are making me unhappy by leaving me!

sentences.original: nicawâc nika-mahîhkaniwin, itwêw aw âwâsis, êh-ati-sipwêpahtât.
sentences.english: All I can do is turn into a wolf,” cried the child, and ran away from there.

sentences.original: mahîhkaniwiw; ôhôwôwô â, êkosi êkwah êkoyikohk êyôkôw âtayôhkêwin.
sentences.text: mahîhkaniwiw â êkosi êkwa êkoyikohk êwako âtayôhkêwin
sentences.english: He turned into a wolf. “Ohowowo!”
